channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: GAO: Bergdahl Exchange Violated Law
item.description: Congressional investigators say the Pentagon broke the law when it swapped Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, held prisoner in Afghanistan for five years, for five Taliban leaders.
item.content:encoded:
Congressional investigators say the Pentagon broke the law when it swapped Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, held prisoner in Afghanistan for five years, for five Taliban leaders.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Hamas Admits To Kidnapping And Killing Israeli Teens
item.description: The leader of the group says it carried out the kidnapping in the hopes of exchanging the teens for prisoners held by Israel, and didn't intend to set off the massive conflict that followed.
item.content:encoded:
The leader of the group says it carried out the kidnapping in the hopes of exchanging the teens for prisoners held by Israel, and didn't intend to set off the massive conflict that followed.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Contagious Kisses? We Answer Your Questions About Ebola Recovery
item.description: Two Americans were released Thursday from an Atlanta hospital after treatment for Ebola. The news has generated a flurry of questions about what happens after you survive Ebola. So we asked the CDC.
item.content:encoded:
Two Americans were released Thursday from an Atlanta hospital after treatment for Ebola. The news has generated a flurry of questions about what happens after you survive Ebola. So we asked the CDC.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Linda Poon

item.title: In Covering Foley's Killing, Media Outlets Face A Difficult Choice
item.description: The execution of the American journalist James Foley by ISIS casts new attention on how news organizations cover graphic violence, and how they cover the risks taken by their own colleagues and peers.
item.content:encoded:
The execution of the American journalist James Foley by ISIS casts new attention on how news organizations cover graphic violence, and how they cover the risks taken by their own colleagues and peers.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: David Folkenflik

item.title: Islamic State 'Beyond Anything We've Seen,' Hagel Says
item.description: The secretary of defense says the extremists are well-funded and organized and that he expects them to "regroup and stage an offensive" despite U.S. airstrikes.
item.content:encoded:
The secretary of defense says the extremists are well-funded and organized and that he expects them to "regroup and stage an offensive" despite U.S. airstrikes.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Can Quinoa Take Root On The 'Roof Of The World'?
item.description: Quinoa, once a homebody crop, crossed the Atlantic for the first time this century. Now the Food and Agriculture Organization has a hunch it can thrive in Central and Southwest Asia.
item.content:encoded:
Quinoa, once a homebody crop, crossed the Atlantic for the first time this century. Now the Food and Agriculture Organization has a hunch it can thrive in Central and Southwest Asia.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Dan Charles

item.title: European Fighters Take On More Prominent Roles In The Islamic State
item.description: The hunt is on to identify the man in the James Foley execution video who speaks with a British accent. An estimated 2,000 Europeans have left home to join the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq.
item.content:encoded:
The hunt is on to identify the man in the James Foley execution video who speaks with a British accent. An estimated 2,000 Europeans have left home to join the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: The Dynamics Of Demanding Ransom From Nations
item.description: Since the release of a video depicting the killing of American journalist James Foley, it has been revealed that the militant group Islamic State demanded millions of dollars for his freedom. Rukmini Callimachi of The New York Times explains how militant groups use ransom demands such as these for funding.
item.content:encoded:
Since the release of a video depicting the killing of American journalist James Foley, it has been revealed that the militant group Islamic State demanded millions of dollars for his freedom. Rukmini Callimachi of The New York Times explains how militant groups use ransom demands such as these for funding.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Failed Foley Rescue Reveals Challenges Faced By U.S. Intelligence
item.description: Earlier in the summer, a U.S. raid failed to rescue American hostages in Syria, including journalist James Foley, who was executed in a video released this week by Islamist militants. The hostages were not where they were thought to be. NPR's Dina Temple-Raston discusses the limits on America's ability to gather intelligence in Syria, as well as the latest developments since Foley was killed.
item.content:encoded:
Earlier in the summer, a U.S. raid failed to rescue American hostages in Syria, including journalist James Foley, who was executed in a video released this week by Islamist militants. The hostages were not where they were thought to be. NPR's Dina Temple-Raston discusses the limits on America's ability to gather intelligence in Syria, as well as the latest developments since Foley was killed.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Dina Temple-Raston

item.title: American Ebola Patients Leave Atlanta Hospital Healthy
item.description: Two U.S. missionaries who caught the Ebola virus in Liberia have been discharged from an Atlanta hospital after fully recovering. They were the first known Ebola patients flown to the U.S. for treatment. Both received an experimental drug called ZMapp, but it remains unclear what role that treatment played in their recovery.
item.content:encoded:
Two U.S. missionaries who caught the Ebola virus in Liberia have been discharged from an Atlanta hospital after fully recovering. They were the first known Ebola patients flown to the U.S. for treatment. Both received an experimental drug called ZMapp, but it remains unclear what role that treatment played in their recovery.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Audie Cornish

item.title: Why Ebola Is Making It Harder To Provide Good Health Care
item.description: People are afraid to go to the doctor. Clinics have lost staff to the virus. Basic supplies aren't there. Ebola will have an impact on everything from malaria treatment to maternal health.
item.content:encoded:
People are afraid to go to the doctor. Clinics have lost staff to the virus. Basic supplies aren't there. Ebola will have an impact on everything from malaria treatment to maternal health.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Richard Harris

item.title: The Siege Deepens In Eastern Ukraine's Donetsk
item.description: There are reports of heavy shelling on the outskirts of Donetsk in eastern Ukraine, as government forces try to take the city from pro-Russian separatists. Meanwhile, thousands of the city's residents are trying to flee the fighting.
item.content:encoded:
There are reports of heavy shelling on the outskirts of Donetsk in eastern Ukraine, as government forces try to take the city from pro-Russian separatists. Meanwhile, thousands of the city's residents are trying to flee the fighting.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson

item.title: Israel Unrolls New Series Of Strikes Against Hamas Leadership
item.description: An Israeli airstrike killed three Hamas military commanders, who were buried shortly later amid threats that the militant group would respond.
item.content:encoded:
An Israeli airstrike killed three Hamas military commanders, who were buried shortly later amid threats that the militant group would respond.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Philip Reeves

item.title: A Year Later, Syria's Chemical Weapons Are Gone, But Siege Remains
item.description: The Damascus suburb hit by a deadly chemical weapons attack a year ago remains surrounded by Syrian government forces who are still trying to squeeze the rebels out.
item.content:encoded:
The Damascus suburb hit by a deadly chemical weapons attack a year ago remains surrounded by Syrian government forces who are still trying to squeeze the rebels out.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Alison Meuse

item.title: The 10-Year-Old Boy Has Died, Probably Of Ebola
item.description: The photo showed a little boy. He was found naked on a beach in Liberia and was very sick, most likely with Ebola. The world was deeply touched. And hoped for a miracle. But his story has a sad end.
item.content:encoded:
The photo showed a little boy. He was found naked on a beach in Liberia and was very sick, most likely with Ebola. The world was deeply touched. And hoped for a miracle. But his story has a sad end.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Marc Silver
